threads.title: Junkanoo Mask Texture Techniques - Need Help!
threads.content: Hi everyone! I'm working on my Junkanoo mask assignment and struggling with getting the metallic texture right for the decorative elements. The reference photos show this amazing iridescent quality that I can't seem to replicate in Blender. Has anyone worked with similar materials? Would love to see your approach!

attachments.caption: Work in progress - missing the metallic shine

posts.content: Hey Kiana! I had the same issue. Try using the Principled BSDF with high metallic value (0.9) and low roughness (0.1). The key is in the normal map - you need subtle variations to catch the light properly.

Excellent question, Kiana! Marcus is on the right track. I'd also recommend studying real Junkanoo pieces at the National Art Gallery. The way light plays on the aluminum and sequins is quite complex. For your digital version, consider using multiple material layers with different reflection properties.
I created a tutorial on this exact topic! Check out my video on creating authentic Caribbean metallic textures. Link in my profile. @Kiana hope this helps!

threads.title: Cultural Research Resources - Building Our Shared Library
threads.content: Let's build a comprehensive resource library together! Please share any cultural references, museum pieces, or traditional craft techniques you discover during your research. This will benefit everyone in the class.

posts.content: Found some amazing historical photos of straw work from the 1960s at the Archives. The geometric patterns could translate beautifully to 3D form.

threads.title: First Rake and Scrape Recording - Feedback Welcome!
threads.content: Just finished my first attempt at recording a traditional rake and scrape piece. I tried to stay authentic while adding some modern production touches. What do you think? Any suggestions for improvement?

posts.content: Really nice work! The guitar tone is spot on. I'd suggest bringing the percussion up in the mix a bit - it's the heartbeat of rake and scrape. Also, that little melodic run at 2:15 is perfect!
